metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: A HashMap is a collection of key/value pairs.
content.html: A HashMap is a collection of key/value pairs.

content.text: HashMaps are great when you want to store values and find them by a key.
content.html: HashMaps are great when you want to store values and find them by a key.

content.text: To use HashMap, you must import it from Rust's standard library:
content.html: To use HashMap, you must import it from Rust's standard library:

content.code_html: use std::collections::HashMap;

content.text: You can create a new, empty HashMap and add items to it:
content.html: You can create a new, empty HashMap and add items to it:

content.code_html:
// Import HashMap
use std::collections::HashMap;

fn main() {
  // Create a HashMap called capitalCities
  let mut capitalCities = HashMap::new();

  // Add keys and values (Country, City)
  capitalCities.insert("England", "London");
  capitalCities.insert("Germany", "Berlin");
  capitalCities.insert("Norway", "Oslo");

  println!("{:?}", capitalCities);
}

content.text: You can use the .get() method to access a value in a HashMap by its key:
content.html: You can use the .get() method to access a value in a HashMap by its key:

content.code_html:
let mut capitalCities = HashMap::new();

capitalCities.insert("England", "London");
capitalCities.insert("Germany", "Berlin");
capitalCities.insert("Norway", "Oslo");

if let Some(city) = capitalCities.get("England") {
  println!("The capital of England is {}.", city);
} else {
  println!("England is not in the map.");
}

content.text: If you insert a new value using a key that already exists, the old value is replaced with the new one:
content.html: If you insert a new value using a key that already exists, the old value is replaced with the new one:

content.code_html:
let mut capitalCities = HashMap::new();

capitalCities.insert("England", "London");
capitalCities.insert("England", "Berlin");

println!("{:?}", capitalCities);

content.text: To remove a key from a HashMap, use the .remove() method:
content.html: To remove a key from a HashMap, use the .remove() method:

content.code_html:
let mut capitalCities = HashMap::new();

// Add keys and values (Country, City)
 capitalCities.insert("England", "London");
capitalCities.insert("Germany", "Berlin");
capitalCities.insert("Norway", "Oslo");

// Remove the key "England"
 capitalCities.remove("England");

println!("{:?}", capitalCities);

content.text: You can use a for loop to go through all key/value pairs:
content.html: You can use a for loop to go through all key/value pairs:

content.code_html:
let mut capitalCities = HashMap::new();

// Add keys and values (Country, City)
capitalCities.insert("England", "London");
capitalCities.insert("Germany", "Berlin");
capitalCities.insert("Norway", "Oslo");

// Loop through the HashMap
for (country, city) in &capitalCities {
  println!("The capital of {} is {}.", country, city);
}

content.text: Note: HashMaps require keys to be unique. Inserting the same key again will overwrite the old value.
content.html: Note: HashMaps require keys to be unique. Inserting the same key again will overwrite the old value.
